title: Second impeachment of Donald Trump
added: After the [[2021 storming of the United States Capitol|storming of the U.S. Capitol]], [[Ohio]] [[Mike DeWine|Governor Mike DeWine]] stated that impeachment was not a wise idea, saying "...if that were to occur more people would be inflamed," along with ”There would be less trust in the whole system. We only got two more weeks and the next president will take place at 12 noon on January 20, two weeks to go and that will be it.”<ref>{{Cite web|last=Schneider|first=Jeremy|title=DeWine calls Capitol riots sad day in American history|url=https://www.13abc.com/2021/01/07/dewine-calls-capitol-riots-sad-day-in-american-history/|access-date=2021-01-14|website=https://www.13abc.com|language=en}}</ref>

title: Second impeachment of Donald Trump
deleted: [[Category:2021 storming of the United States Capitol|Efforts to remove Donald Trump from office]]

title: Second impeachment of Donald Trump
added: On January 26, Senator [[Rand Paul]] (R-[[Kentucky|KY]]) tweeted "This impeachment is nothing more than a partisan exercise designed to further divide the country. Democrats claim to want unify the country but impeaching a former president, a private citizen, is the antithesis of unity."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/535916-rand-paul-bashes-democrats-over-impeachment-trial-the-antithesis-of-unity|title=Rand Paul bashes Democrats over impeachment trial: 'the antithesis of unity'|publisher=thehill.com|date=January 26, 2021}}</ref>

title: Second impeachment of Donald Trump
added: The House impeachment managers formally triggered the start of the [[Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump|impeachment trial]] on January 25 by walking across the Capitol and delivered to the [[United States Senate|Senate]] the charge against Trump. The nine managers walked two-by-two led into the Senate chamber by the lead impeachment manager, who read the article of impeachment.<ref name=delivery/> The trial in the Senate is scheduled to start on February 9.<ref name=date/>

title: Second impeachment of Donald Trump
deleted: }}{{2021 storming of the United States Capitol}}

title: Second impeachment of Donald Trump
deleted: In total, 36 Republicans have said they oppose conviction so far.

title: Second impeachment of Donald Trump
deleted: On January 26, Senators were sworn in for the impeachment trial.<ref>[https://edition.cnn.com/2021/01/26/politics/impeachment-trial-latest-senators-sworn-in/index.html Senators sworn in for Trump impeachment trial ]</ref>

Before the swearing-in, Senator [[Tom Cotton]], a Republican ally of the former President, claimed the Senate lacks the constitutional authority to conduct an impeachment trial of a former president.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Cotton Statement on Senate Impeachment Proceedings {{!}} U.S. Senator Cotton of Arkansas |url=https://www.cotton.senate.gov/news/press-releases/cotton-statement-on-senate-impeachment-proceedings|access-date=January 14, 2021 |website=www.cotton.senate.gov|archive-date=January 14, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210114192340/https://www.cotton.senate.gov/news/press-releases/cotton-statement-on-senate-impeachment-proceedings|url-status=live}}</ref> However, legal scholars [[Brian C. Kalt]] and Frank O. Bowman III say "there is strong historical evidence" for the concept of impeaching an official who has already left office, what is technically termed "late impeachment." Ten states "between 1776 and 1787" mentioned impeachment in their constitutions, and half of those "specifically permitted late impeachment; no state explicitly forbade it."<ref>{{Cite news|last=Kalt|first=Brian C.|date=11 January 2021|title=Congress can impeach Trump now and convict him when he's gone|work=Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/2021/01/11/trump-impeachment-senate-trial/|url-status=live|access-date=14 January 2021|archive-date=January 14, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210114000753/https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/2021/01/11/trump-impeachment-senate-trial/}}</ref> Moreover, the precedent was established when Secretary of War [[William W. Belknap#Senate trial and acquittal|William Belknap]] was acquitted in 1876. The objection to the trial based on its purported unconstitutionality because Trump was no longer in office was defeated on a 55–45 vote, with all Democrats and five Republicans voting against the objection.<ref name="Fandos">Nicholas Fandos, [https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/01/26/us/biden-trump-impeachment#impeachment-charge-senate Republicans vote en masse against trying Trump, signaling he is likely to be acquitted of the impeachment charge.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210209185542/https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/01/26/us/biden-trump-impeachment#impeachment-charge-senate |date=February 9, 2021 }}, ''New York Times'' (January 26, 2021).</ref><ref name="HughesWise">Siobhan Hughes & Lindsay Wise, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/republicans-challenge-trump-impeachment-trial-11611683182 Most Republican Senators Reject Constitutionality of Trump Impeachment], ''Wall Street Journal'' (January 26, 2021).</ref> The foregoing was a motion to dismiss; on the question of whether the Senate had jurisdiction to try the impeachment of a former official, the Senate voted 56–44 in favor of proceeding, with [[Bill Cassidy|Senator Cassidy]] providing the additional vote, on February 9.<ref name="Cassidy20200209">Amy B Wang & Seung Min Kim, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/02/09/trump-impeachment-live-updates/#link-BZMCM4GC55F2NHBLKQYEOYXCIY] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210210191022/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/02/09/trump-impeachment-live-updates/#link-BZMCM4GC55F2NHBLKQYEOYXCIY |date=February 10, 2021 }}, ''Washington Post'' (February 09, 2021)</ref> On February 13, the Senate voted against impeachment, with 57 voting for it, below the 67 (two-thirds) required. All Democrats, along with both Independents who caucus with the Democrats, voted to convict, along with seven Republicans. The seven Republicans who voted to convict  Former President Trump were Senators [[Richard Burr|Richard M. Burr]], [[Bill Cassidy]], [[Susan Collins]], [[Lisa Murkowski]], [[Mitt Romney]], [[Ben Sasse]], and [[Pat Toomey|Patrick J. Toomey]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=U.S. Senate: U.S. Senate Roll Call Votes 117th Congress - 1st Session|url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=117&session=1&vote=00059|access-date=2021-02-14|website=www.senate.gov}}</ref>
